title: 111_hr5514
content:
The Act may be cited as the "National Activity Based Total Accountability Act of 2010". The Congress finds that the Federal Government sends billions of dollars to the States annually, including funds for health care, transportation, housing, education, and agriculture through various means such as grants, loans, and direct appropriations. The Federal Government allocates $36 billion for education and $27 billion for agriculture to the States through various means like grants, loans, and direct appropriations. States spend this money on common activities such as health care, transportation, housing, and education. It is important for taxpayers, legislators, and agencies to have access to reliable data for comparing how effectively these funds are being used. States should be able to objectively compare their performance in utilizing Federal taxpayer dollars across various sectors like health care, transportation, housing, education, and agriculture. Activity-based total accountability can identify the most efficient States, promoting competition and effective use of funds. The purpose of this Act is to improve government accountability at the State level by implementing activity-based total accountability to identify the most effective States in utilizing taxpayer dollars, promoting competition, and ensuring the best value for taxpayers. The Act aims to improve government accountability at the State level by requiring annual accountings using total accountability measures, including unit-cost data, to ensure taxpayers get the best value for their dollar. SEC. 3. STATE FISCAL ACCOUNTING REPORTS. Each State receiving Federal financial assistance must submit a State fiscal accounting report to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget 15 days before the end of the fiscal year. The report includes a one-page summary of total funding and expenditures for each budget entity, along with a unit-cost summary for each entity. Each State fiscal accounting report must include a one-page summary listing total funding and expenditures for each budget entity, along with a unit-cost summary for each entity. The Director is required to publish these reports on an Internet website within 30 days of receiving them. SEC. 4. STANDARDIZATION OF STATE FISCAL ACCOUNTING REPORTS. The Director ensures standardized State fiscal accounting reports for comparison. States must submit program descriptions within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The State governments must submit program descriptions to the Director within 180 days of the Act's enactment, detailing activities of each budget entity. The Director will establish a classification system based on this information and relevant data for comparison. The Director will establish a uniform classification system for agency activities based on program descriptions submitted by State governments within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This system will categorize programs and activities into agency activities and identify conduct for each activity unit. The Director will establish a uniform classification system for agency activities based on program descriptions submitted by State governments. This system will categorize programs and activities, identify conduct for each activity unit, and establish performance measures linked to each agency activity. The Director will establish a classification system for agency activities based on program descriptions submitted by State governments. Each agency activity will have performance measures linked to it in reports. SEC. 5. UNIT-COST SUMMARY. Each unit-cost summary for a budget entity of a State government shall be one page long and include funds available, agency activities, and a reconciliation of funds with expenditures. The statement of funds available for a budget entity must identify each source of funds and the amount, including State appropriations and Federal financial assistance. The budget entity must identify sources of funds, including State appropriations, Federal financial assistance, and other sources determined appropriate by the Director. SEC. 7. AGENCY ACTIVITY LINE ITEM LISTINGS. Agency activity line item listings must identify the agency activity, total funds expended, number of activity units, and unit cost. Additionally, they should describe relevant details related to the agency activity. The budget entity must provide details on the agency activity, including the unit cost, purpose, and intended beneficiaries. Special rules apply for determining expenditures for certain agency activities. The budget entity must detail the agency activity, including purpose and intended beneficiaries. Special rules apply for determining expenditures for certain agency activities, where allocation must be consistent with similar activities. The budget entity must allocate expenditures for agency activities without measurable accomplishment to similar activities with methods of measurement. Payments to contractors or subordinate entities must be included in total expenditure amounts. Unit-cost of agency activities must be determined. Payments to contractors or subordinate entities must be included in total expenditure amounts. The unit-cost of agency activities is determined using a specific formula. The formula in paragraph (1) defines UC as the unit-cost of the agency activity, m as the amount in subsection (a)(1)(B), and q as the number in subsection (a)(1)(C). This formula is used for reconciliation of funds available with adjusted expenditures. SEC. 8. RECONCILIATION OF FUNDS AVAILABLE WITH ADJUSTED EXPENDITURES. This section outlines the process for reconciling adjusted expenditures of a budget entity with funds available for expenditure or obligation. Adjusted expenditures are determined by the formula AE = EXP + PT + REV. Definition of terms in formula for reconciling adjusted expenditures:
- AE: Adjusted expenditures
- EXP: Sum of all expenditures by the budget entity for agency activities
- PT: Sum of all pass-throughs identified by the budget entity
- REV: Sum of all reversions identified by the budget entity
A budget entity can identify amounts as pass-throughs or reversions based on criteria set by the Director. If a State government fails to file a timely fiscal accounting report, the Director will notify Federal departments to withhold 10% of financial assistance for the next year. The Director can create necessary rules for this Act. SEC. 11. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "State government," "budget entity," "agency activity," and "Federal financial assistance."
